Award.AwardTitle: MRI Consortium: Development of a Charged Particle Telescope by Undergraduate Research Students for Studies of Exotic Nuclei
Award.AbstractNarration:
Determining the properties of atomic nuclides requires the measurement of particles emitted by this nuclide. Detecting these particles in coincidence with other emitted radiation or particles, such as gamma-rays, neutrons, and charged particles, is difficult due to their different properties. A new charged particle detector system will make experiments requiring detection of these particles together more efficient for experiments performed at facilities such as the National Superconducting Cyclotron Laboratory (NSCL) and soon the Facility for Rare Isotope Beams (FRIB) at Michigan State University (MSU). Also, the development and assembly of this device will provide invaluable training for undergraduate students at Augustana College, Wabash College, and Hope College (small, undergraduate-only, liberal arts institutions), which will help prepare them for graduate school. The funds for this award will support the work of undergraduate students and the primary investigator to purchase, test, and install the new experimental detector system for the use at the NSCL and FRIB.

Experiments on exotic nuclear systems are frequently performed at or near the neutron drip-line to probe changes in nuclear structure. The most straightforward type of experiment involves detecting a single neutron and charged particle resulting from a nuclide decaying from a neutron-unbound state. However, the charged fragment may be in a bound excited state resulting in gamma-ray emission, such as for some neutron-unbound states of F-25 and Be-13. Thus efficient coincident detection of gamma-rays, neutrons, and charged particles is desired. This proposal supports the purchase, development, and installation of a compact charged particle detector telescope that will provide a balance of efficient gamma-ray, neutron, and charged particle detection. This system will be installed at the National Superconducting Cyclotron Laboratory (NSCL) at Michigan State University (MSU), as a radioactive nuclear ion beam facility is needed to produce short-lived nuclides for experimentation. The charged particle detector telescope will detect the charged particle, allow the neutron to pass through with minimal attenuation to then be detected by the MoNA-LISA (Modular Neutron Array and the Large-area multi-Institutional Scintillator Array), and allow gamma-ray detection using compact systems already at the NSCL. Also, this device will also be available for use at Facility for Rare Isotope Beams (FRIB).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A new detection system to enable efficient detection of charged particles, neutrons, and gamma-rays emitted from excited radioactive nuclides was supported by this Major Research Instrumentation award. The detection system is called a charged particle detector telescope, which consists of seven silicon detectors and a single CsI(Tl) crystal to identify charged particles. Experiments using this device require radioactive beams produced by facilities such as the National Superconducting Cyclotron Laboratory (NSCL) located at Michigan State University (MSU) in East Lansing, MI. This project was led and supported by members of the Modular Neutron Array (MoNA) Collaboration, which is a group of researchers that are at Primarily Undergraduate Institutions (PUIs), which means undergraduate researchers contributed to the development, testing, and running of the device. This work enabled the faculty and student researchers in the collaboration to perform a new experiment at the NSCL and learn about a new device that can be used with the first beams of the Facility for Rare Isotope Beams (FRIB).

 

The intellectual merit of this work is to enable new experiments on neutron-rich nuclides that contribute to understanding changes to nuclear structure in very unstable systems. Such neutron-rich nuclides are very short-lived and decay by prompt neutron emission. Most experiments performed by the MoNA Collaboration require measuring the properties of the resulting neutron and charged fragments in coincidence to reconstruct the state of the short-lived nucleus. However, the charged fragments may have long-lived states, which require detecting gamma-rays and neutrons in coincidence to determine its structure, as in the case of neutrons emitted from the unbound nucleus 13Be. This experiment was performed employing the charged particle detector telescope. The charged particle detector telescope array was built and tested by an undergraduate student and PIs. The experiment was performed in September 2020 and shows data with coincidences of neutrons, gamma-rays, and charged particle as intended by this award.

The broader impacts are to develop expertise in the use of new detectors and instrumentation along with providing unique high quality learning experiences for undergraduate students. The Primary Investigators, MoNA Collaboration members, and undergraduate students all learned how the telescope works, how to use the device with digital data acquisition systems, and utilized advanced analysis techniques to maximize the benefit using this type of device. Multiple presentations about this work were conducted at national conferences and publications from the experiment and analysis efforts are expected with student and PI members of the collaboration as coauthors or primary authors. In addition, the understanding of this device will open up new research device ideas for use with FRIB, which requires measuring much heavier charged particles to access exciting new research opportunities in future experiments.
